description: Niger will close public schools from December 17 to January 1, 2021, with all workshops and seminars being banned during this period. UPDATE: The original policy was that in Niger all schools were closed for at least two weeks starting from March 20th. This was updated to Niger opening schools on 1 June and then Niger reopening schools and resuming classes on June 1. Public schools will now close from December 17 through January 1, 2021 with all workshops and seminars being banned.

description: Niger announced a curfew for Niamey from 7 p.m. to 6 a.m. for a period of two weeks renewable starting 28 March
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: Niger announces state of health emergency throughout the national territory as of 27 March

Niger announces state of health emergency throughout the national territory as of 27 March. As of October 10, Niger announced an extension of the state of health emergency throughout the national territory until January 10. UPDATE: The declaration of emergency was announced throughout the national territory as of March 27. As of October 10, the declaration of emergency has been extended for three months.
Land borders in Niger have been closed since March 19, however, merchandise and passengers with special permission are exempt.
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction

description: Niger closed the airports of Niamey and Zinder for a period of two weeks from March 19 onward and the closure of all land borders
type_sub_cat: Total border crossing ban

description: Niger State Task Force on Covid-19 and the Secretary of the Government stated that as of April 29th, everyone, even those eligible to cross, into the State will be examined and screened thoroughly by medical personnel.
type_sub_cat: Health Screenings (e.g. temperature checks)

description: Niger closed the airports of Niamey and Zinder for a period of two week from March 19 onward and the closure of all land borders. International flights into Niger's international airports resumed on August 1, 2020. Land borders in Niger have remained closed, however, passengers with special permission and merchandise are allowed. UPDATE: The original policy was that the airports in Niamey and Zinder were closed for a period of two weeks onward from March 19 and all land borders were also closed. On August 1, 2020 commercial international flights into all of Niger's international airports resumed. However, land borders are still closed, except for people with special permission or those carrying merchandise.
type_sub_cat: Total border crossing ban

description: Niger reinforces temperature control and hygiene measures at the various entrances and exits of the cities, March 20
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: Niger recruits 1500 health workers, establishment of testing centres in each regional capital
type_sub_cat: Other Heath Staff
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: Niger continued to carry out a few special and humanitarian flights since the start of June. The protocol included: hand and baggage disinfection, temperature control, containment and testing (for some) of 2,977 passengers since the airports closed. As of June 26th, on the special flights, 68 people were detected positive and taken care of and their contacts were also confined.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description: Niger announces the closure of railway stations and suspension of public ground transport for a period of one week, renewable from 21 March
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: Niger announces the closure of railway stations and suspension of public ground transport for a period of one week, renewable from 21 March. As of May 14, the ban on intercity travel in Niger has ended. UPDATE: The original internal border restrictions were set to last for a period of one week, renewable from March 21. One May 14, the ban on intercity travel was lifted.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: Niger is planning on launching a country-wide food and cash distribution operation for all the families affected by the restrictions on the Transport sector. This operation will concern 4,054 households, or 28,376 beneficiary people, over a period of five months, starting May 5th.
type_text: The policy refers to the economical aspect of the country and isn't related to restrictions on sectors or lockdowns. This policy has to do with the financial relief policies that Niger is beginning to implement on specific groups of people.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Niger's government is increasing their 2020 general state budget from 2.266.15 billion to 2.405.53 billion, an increase of 139.38 billion, corresponding to 6.15%, due to Covid-19â€™s negative socio-economic consequences. This was announced on May 8, 2020 and is effective immediately.
type_text: This policy has to do with the national economic relief policies in terms of monetary value.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Beginning on August 1, 2020 all airline passengers arriving in Niger are expected to self-quarantine for 14 days. Any passenger arriving in Niger who tests positive for COVID-19 at the airports will be isolated at a governmental isolation site at the passenger's expense.
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Beginning on August 1, 2020 all airline passengers arriving in Niger are expected to self-quarantine for 14 days. Any passenger arriving in Niger who tests positive for COVID-19 at the airports will be isolated at a governmental isolation site at the passenger's expense.

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Niger has banned all gatherings with at least 1,000 people UPDATE: March 13 gatherings with at least 1,000 people were prohibited
Niger announced the ban of all groups of 50 persons or more from March 18th

Niger prohibits public gatherings, especially at weddings, baptisms, foyandi and funerals. It welcomes and supports the decision taken by the Religious Leaders (Ulemas and Christians) March 19 to ban collective prayers and the closure of places of worship, March 20
Niger announced the end of closure of places of worship and reopened them since May 13, 2020. The end date was not originally stated at the start of the policy.
Niger welcomes and supports the decision taken by the Religious Leaders (Ulemas and Christians), in particular, the ban on collective prayers and the closure of places of worship, 19 March.
Niger announced that a distance of at least one meter must be observed from March 18th onward

Niger: the capital Niamey is requiring people to wear face masks in all urban transport, in markets, supermarkets, shops, public squares of the capital from April 11 UPDATE: Now wearing masks is mandatory in Niamey in all urban transport, in markets, supermarkets, shops, public squares of the capital
Niger announced that all citizens should wear masks April 22 UPDATE: Niger announces that all citizens should wear maks on April 22
